title: Getting Phlegm out of Your Throat Without the Use of Medicine

steps.title: Gargle with warm salt water to relieve mucus and soothe your throat.
steps.content: Gargle with warm salt water to relieve mucus and soothe your throat. Mix .5 tablespoons (7.4 mL) of salt into one glass of warm water. [1] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Take a sip of salt water, but don’t swallow. Instead, tilt your head back and gargle the water for 30-45 seconds. Then, spit out the salt water in the sink and rinse out your mouth. [2] X Research source You can repeat this treatment 2-4 times a day, as needed.

steps.title: Use a cool-mist humidifier to moisten your throat and airways.
steps.content: Use a cool-mist humidifier to moisten your throat and airways. Pour distilled water into your humidifier up to the fill line. Then, turn on the humidifier and keep it running while you recover. The mist will moisten your airways and thin your mucus. This should relieve the phlegm in your throat. [3] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Eucalyptus essential oil , an active ingredient in VapoRub products, can help loosen phlegm in your chest. [4] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you decide to add it to your diffuser, follow the manufacturer’s instructions on the label and ensure the space is well ventilated. [5] X Trustworthy Source American Lung Association Nonprofit health organization dedicated to improving lung health through education, advocacy, and research Go to source

steps.title: Take a hot shower and inhale the steam for temporary relief.
steps.content: Take a hot shower and inhale the steam for temporary relief. Since steam can loosen built-up phlegm, taking a steamy shower may help. [6] X Research source Set your water temperature to hot but not scalding. Then, relax in your shower and take deep breaths .

steps.title: Inhale steam from a bowl of hot water to thin and loosen the phlegm.
steps.content: Inhale steam from a bowl of hot water to thin and loosen the phlegm. Fill a large bowl with steaming hot water and let it cool for one minute. Then, lean over the bowl and drape a towel over your head and the bowl. Slowly inhale the steam for 10-15 minutes. [7] X Research source This is called a facial steam . You can do it once or twice a day to get relief, or at times when you’re most aware of your symptoms. Many people inhale eucalyptus steam to loosen phlegm in their chest and relieve congestion. [8] X Research source Put a few drops of essential oil into a bowl of hot water before placing a towel over your head and breathing in the steam. [9] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Research shows that steam inhalation may scald your face. [10] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source If you choose to do this method, be sure to maintain a safe distance from the bowl. Do not put your face so close that your skin feels like it’s burning or you’re having trouble breathing fresh air.

steps.title: Hum to break up the phlegm if your throat doesn’t hurt.
steps.content: Hum to break up the phlegm if your throat doesn’t hurt. Humming makes your throat vibrate, which may help break up mucus. [11] X Research source Pick your favorite song, then hum for a minute or 2. Follow up with a few sips of water. This can help clear your throat. This works best if your throat isn’t sore. If humming feels uncomfortable, try something else.

steps.title: Rinse your sinuses with a neti pot to clear your airways and thin mucus.
steps.content: Rinse your sinuses with a neti pot to clear your airways and thin mucus. Fill a neti pot with an over-the-counter saline rinse (made with distilled or sterile water). Then, lean over a sink and tilt your head to one side. Breathing through your open mouth, place the spout of the neti pot against your top nostril, then slowly pour the water into your nose. The water should go in your top nostril and exit your bottom nostril. [12] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source Rinse both of your nostrils over the sink. Allow the solution and any excess mucus to drip out, blowing your nose to clear the nasal passage. [13] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Never use tap water in your neti pot. Some tap water contains amoebas that can lead to serious infections. Only use distilled, sterile, or filtered water, or tap water that has been boiled for 3-5 minutes and cooled until it is lukewarm. [14] X Trustworthy Source US Food and Drug Administration U.S. government agency responsible for promoting public health Go to source

steps.title: Stay hydrated by drinking at least 6-8 glasses of water per day.
steps.content: Stay hydrated by drinking at least 6-8 glasses of water per day. Fluids will help thin out the mucus so that it doesn’t build up in your throat. [15] X Research source Make sure you stay hydrated by drinking plenty of water, tea , and other beverages. Additionally, snack on foods that contain water, like soup or fruit. Women need about 11.5 cups (2.7 L) of water daily, while men need about 15.5 cups (3.7 L) of water daily. [16] X Trustworthy Source Harvard Medical School Harvard Medical School's Educational Site for the Public Go to source Try flavoring your water with lemon or diluted juice if you dislike drinking plain water. [17] X Research source Add lemon slices to your water or squeeze some lemon juice into your glass.

steps.title: Drink warm liquids to clear your throat and break up the mucus.
steps.content: Drink warm liquids to clear your throat and break up the mucus. Studies show that drinking hot water or chicken soup can clear mucus and your nasal passages. [19] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source The heat of the fluid will soften and thin the mucus so it drains away more easily. Drinking warm liquids can also soothe a sore throat and help you stay hydrated. [20] X Research source

steps.title: Sip on lemon water with honey to soothe your throat and clear mucus.
steps.content: Sip on lemon water with honey to soothe your throat and clear mucus. Add 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of lemon juice to 1 cup (240 mL) of hot water. Then, stir 1 tablespoon (15 mL) of honey into the lemon water. Drink your tea while it’s warm to loosen thick mucus and relieve a cough. [22] X Research source The acid in the lemon juice helps to thin and remove the phlegm, while the honey soothes your throat. You can enjoy your lemon water with honey as often as you’d like.

steps.title: Eat hot soup to thin and break up mucus.
steps.content: Eat hot soup to thin and break up mucus. Soup warms the mucus in your throat, which can thin it out so it goes away easily. It can also help relieve pain and sinus pressure. [23] X Research source Additionally, studies show that eating chicken noodle soup can reduce inflammation. [24] X Research source

steps.title: Eat spicy foods to loosen the phlegm so it drains easily.
steps.content: Eat spicy foods to loosen the phlegm so it drains easily. Choose dishes that contain spices like cayenne pepper, chili pepper, wasabi, horseradish, or peppers. These spices contain capsaicin, which can break up mucus and cause your nose to run. This should help clear your phlegm. [25] X Research source Spices can upset your stomach, so you may not want to try this if you have a history of gastrointestinal issues.

steps.title: Keep your head elevated so mucus won’t collect in your throat.
steps.content: Keep your head elevated so mucus won’t collect in your throat. Mucus naturally drains from your sinuses down the back of your throat. If you’re lying down, the mucus can pool there. This leads to a buildup of phlegm in your throat. To prevent this, prop yourself up on pillows to allow the phlegm to drain. [26] X Research source When you’re sleeping, use a lot of pillows or sleep in a chair if your mucus is really thick.

steps.title: Stop eating foods that cause you to have acid reflux.
steps.content: Stop eating foods that cause you to have acid reflux. Acid reflux can cause mucus to collect in your throat. If you commonly experience heartburn or burning in your throat, monitor the foods that seem to cause your symptoms. Then, avoiding eating those foods. [27] X Research source Common foods that cause acid reflux include: garlic, onions, spicy foods, caffeine, carbonated drinks, citrus foods, onions, alcohol, mint, tomato products, chocolate, and fried, greasy foods. [28] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source Talk to your doctor if you’re having acid reflux more than twice a week, if you haven’t already.

steps.title: Avoid smoking and stay away from secondhand smoke.
steps.content: Avoid smoking and stay away from secondhand smoke. Smoking can dry out your vocal cords, which triggers your body to make more phlegm and mucus to restore the lost moisture. This can make your phlegm worse. It’s best to stop smoking if you do. Additionally, ask others not to smoke around you or step away while they do it. [29] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source If you’re a smoker, you may be able to use nicotine gum or patches to help you deal with your cravings.

steps.title: Avoid dairy products because they can thicken your mucus.
steps.content: Avoid dairy products because they can thicken your mucus. You may have heard that drinking milk increases mucus production, but studies show that it’s not true. [30] X Trustworthy Source PubMed Central Journal archive from the U.S. National Institutes of Health Go to source It does, however, temporarily thicken your saliva and coat your throat, making it harder to swallow. [31] X Trustworthy Source Dairy Council of California Resource center focused on providing nutrition education to help consumers make healthy choices about eating and lifestyle habits. Go to source While you might not experience thicker mucus, consider staying away from dairy if you’re trying to get rid of phlegm.

steps.title: Avoid exposure to allergens, fumes, and hazardous chemicals.
steps.content: Avoid exposure to allergens, fumes, and hazardous chemicals. Paint fumes, cleaners, and other chemicals can irritate your airways and harm your respiratory function. This can trigger your body to produce more mucus. Limit your contact with irritants or chemicals. If you must come into contact with them, wear a face mask and move to a ventilated area as soon as possible. [32] X Trustworthy Source Cleveland Clinic Educational website from one of the world's leading hospitals Go to source
